Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

response.output: Gene expression patterns, influenced by the interplay of genes in context-specific networks, are crucial for understanding and predicting disease etiology and drug mechanisms [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. However, existing knowledge gaps and methods limit our ability to comprehensively analyze the complex relationship between gene variations, functional roles, and disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To address this challenge, this study aims to elucidate how genes influence complex traits by investigating the regulation of gene expression across different cell types and their implications for improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. While previous studies have focused on identifying regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], this study aims to integrate functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] to advance the understanding of transcriptional mechanisms underlying tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. By filling this gap in the current literature, this study not only contributes to the broader field of genetic studies and functional genomics but also provides valuable insights into potential therapeutic targets, drug repurposing strategies, and the clustering of complex traits.

response.output:
The current understanding of genetic associations with disease etiology and drug mechanisms is limited by the lack of comprehensive, high-resolution gene expression data across diverse cell types. This gap in knowledge hampers efforts to identify functional relationships between genes, particularly in the context of complex traits that are influenced by multiple regulatory DNA elements. Addressing this shortcoming is crucial for improving treatments and uncovering novel therapeutic targets. In this study, we developed a novel approach that integrates gene co-expression networks with genome-wide association studies (GWAS) data to identify functional relationships between genes in the context of complex traits. Our method enables the identification of dysregulated transcriptional mechanisms that underlie tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies, thereby providing insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

Here, we propose a new approach that combines gene co-expression networks with GWAS data to fill this gap in knowledge. Our method allows us to identify functional relationships between genes in the context of complex traits by examining gene expression patterns across diverse cell types. By doing so, we can shed light on the mechanisms underlying tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies, which are critical for understanding disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

In conclusion, our findings highlight the potential of this novel approach to improve our understanding of genetic associations with disease etiology and drug mechanisms by providing a more comprehensive view of gene expression patterns across diverse cell types. This, in turn, has significant broader implications for the identification of functional relationships between genes and the discovery of new therapeutic targets, ultimately leading to improved treatments for various diseases.

response.output:
In the context of gene expression patterns and complex traits, current literature highlights the importance of understanding how genes collaborate in context-specific networks to influence disease processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. However, there is a gap in knowledge regarding the mechanistic understanding of gene regulation across different cell types and how it affects complex traits [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2019-02009]. This lack of understanding hampers the development of improved treatments for diseases, as evidenced by previous studies on regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-2559-3]. To address this gap, we propose a novel approach that integrates functional genomics data and GWAS data to identify transcriptional mechanisms underlying tissue-specific pathology [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890]. By doing so, we expect to elucidate the connections between gene regulation and complex traits, ultimately contributing to the development of more effective treatments for diseases.

In this study, our method first integrates functional genomics data with GWAS data to identify transcriptional mechanisms underlying tissue-specific pathology. This approach allows us to fill the existing knowledge gap on gene regulation across different cell types and how it affects complex traits. Through the integration of these two types of data, we hope to enhance our understanding of the connections between gene regulation and disease processes. Ultimately, this research has the potential to inform the development of novel therapeutic targets and improve treatment strategies for diseases affected by complex traits.

Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.test_description: Has no spelling errors
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output:
Gene expression patterns have been implicated in the etiology of various diseases, and understanding how genes regulate these patterns is essential for developing targeted treatments. However, existing knowledge on gene co-expression networks, genetic associations, and functional genomics has not yet provided a comprehensive framework to address this gap. In this study, we aim to bridge this gap by utilizing gene expression data and integrating it with genetic association studies to uncover the underlying mechanisms of disease development and drug action. By doing so, we hope to identify novel therapeutic targets and promote drug repurposing efforts.

Here, we have employed a novel approach that combines functional genomics data and GWAS data to shed light on the transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, contribute to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. Our analysis revealed significant associations between gene co-expression patterns and complex traits, highlighting the potential of this method in uncovering disease etiologies and drug action mechanisms. Moreover, our findings have broader significance, as they pave the way for improved treatments and personalized medicine strategies.

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data can improve the identification of transcriptional mechanisms involved in disease development and drug action. This approach not only fills a gap in existing knowledge but also offers a promising avenue for future research, with the potential to advance our understanding of complex traits, disease etiologies, and drug mechanisms.

response.output: Despite the fact that genes collaborate in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and impact disease-relevant biological processes, determining how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different cell types. Previous studies have described various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that are dysregulated in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies. However, there is still a gap in our understanding of how gene co-expression patterns highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which is crucial for the development of novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing strategies. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by employing a novel method that integrates genetic studies with functional genomics data to uncover the underlying connections between gene expression patterns, disease mechanisms, and potential drug targets. By doing so, we will provide insights into the broader context of understanding gene regulation in complex traits and contribute to the development of more effective treatments for various diseases.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. response.output: Despite advances in understanding the role of genes in context-specific networks and their impact on disease-relevant biological processes, determining how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different cell types. This understanding should lead to improved treatments for diseases. Although previous studies have described various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues, integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has not yet effectively captured the full extent of these transcriptional mechanisms. Here, we present a novel approach that fills this gap by systematically analyzing gene co-expression patterns in conjunction with genetic studies and functional genomics data to identify key regulators of gene expression and their role in disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This study not only contributes to the growing body of knowledge on gene regulation but also provides valuable insights into potential therapeutic targets and opportunities for drug repurposing, ultimately advancing our understanding of the broader context in which genes operate.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output:
Genes operate in context-specific networks to carry out various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations within these genes can modify their functional roles, affecting disease-relevant biological processes at a higher level [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires elucidating expression regulation across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to more effective treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including the genetic impact on gene expression across distinct tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms, which are often dysregulated and result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3].

In this revised version, the paragraph is rephrased to provide a clearer and more concise understanding of the importance of integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data in identifying transcriptional mechanisms that contribute to disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output:
In the field of functional genomics, it is well established that genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. However, there is a gap in our understanding of how variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To address this knowledge gap, the current study aims to determine how genes influence complex traits by mechanistically understanding gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which is crucial for improving treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Building upon previous studies that have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across various tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], this research aims to integrate functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] to enhance our understanding of the transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314]. In doing so, this study aims to fill the existing gap in knowledge and contribute to the broader field of functional genomics by providing insights into gene expression regulation, its connection to disease etiology, and potential therapeutic targets.

In conclusion, our research seeks to address the current limitations in understanding gene function and expression patterns by integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data. This integration has the potential to significantly improve our understanding of transcriptional mechanisms that are crucial for elucidating disease etiology and identifying novel therapeutic targets. Our findings will not only fill an existing knowledge gap but also contribute to the broader field by offering a more comprehensive view of gene function, expression regulation, and their role in complex traits and diseases.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genetic studies have shown that genes collaborate in context-specific networks to perform various functions, and their variations can change their functional roles and impact disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. However, understanding how these genes influence complex traits requires investigating expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Existing research has described various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-2559-3]. However, there is a gap in the literature on how to integrate functional genomics data and GWAS data to identify transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890]. This study aims to address this gap by proposing a novel method that integrates functional genomics data and GWAS data, allowing for the identification of transcriptional mechanisms associated with disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genes collaborate within context-specific networks to perform various functions, as demonstrated by [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can impact their functional roles and ultimately affect disease-related biological processes, such as [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To elucidate the influence of genes on complex traits, it is crucial to understand gene expression regulation across different cell types, which may lead to more effective treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic impacts on gene expression across multiple tissues, e.g., [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. The integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data, such as [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890], has aided in the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, can result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/0810772105].

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: The existing literature has identified the significance of genes working together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and how variations in these genes can affect disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. However, there is a gap in the understanding of how genes influence complex traits through expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], a knowledge gap that needs to be addressed for improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. To fill this gap, our research integrates functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890], a method that has shown potential in improving the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. By addressing this gap and providing a comprehensive understanding of gene regulation, our research aims to contribute significantly to the field of genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, and drug repurposing by highlighting disease etiology and elucidating drug mechanisms.

---
 Gene expression patterns, influenced by the interplay of genes in context-specific networks, are crucial for understanding and predicting disease etiology and drug mechanisms [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. However, existing knowledge gaps and methods limit our ability to comprehensively analyze the complex relationship between gene variations, functional roles, and disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To address this challenge, this study aims to elucidate how genes influence complex traits by investigating the regulation of gene expression across different cell types and their implications for improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. While previous studies have focused on identifying regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], this study aims to integrate functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] to advance the understanding of transcriptional mechanisms underlying tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. By filling this gap in the current literature, this study not only contributes to the broader field of genetic studies and functional genomics but also provides valuable insights into potential therapeutic targets, drug repurposing strategies, and the clustering of complex traits.

---
 The current understanding of genetic associations with disease etiology and drug mechanisms is limited by the lack of comprehensive, high-resolution gene expression data across diverse cell types. This gap in knowledge hampers efforts to identify functional relationships between genes, particularly in the context of complex traits that are influenced by multiple regulatory DNA elements. Addressing this shortcoming is crucial for improving treatments and uncovering novel therapeutic targets. In this study, we developed a novel approach that integrates gene co-expression networks with genome-wide association studies (GWAS) data to identify functional relationships between genes in the context of complex traits. Our method enables the identification of dysregulated transcriptional mechanisms that underlie tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies, thereby providing insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

Here, we propose a new approach that combines gene co-expression networks with GWAS data to fill this gap in knowledge. Our method allows us to identify functional relationships between genes in the context of complex traits by examining gene expression patterns across diverse cell types. By doing so, we can shed light on the mechanisms underlying tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies, which are critical for understanding disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

In conclusion, our findings highlight the potential of this novel approach to improve our understanding of genetic associations with disease etiology and drug mechanisms by providing a more comprehensive view of gene expression patterns across diverse cell types. This, in turn, has significant broader implications for the identification of functional relationships between genes and the discovery of new therapeutic targets, ultimately leading to improved treatments for various diseases.

---
 In the context of gene expression patterns and complex traits, current literature highlights the importance of understanding how genes collaborate in context-specific networks to influence disease processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. However, there is a gap in knowledge regarding the mechanistic understanding of gene regulation across different cell types and how it affects complex traits [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2019-02009]. This lack of understanding hampers the development of improved treatments for diseases, as evidenced by previous studies on regulatory DNA elements and genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-2559-3]. To address this gap, we propose a novel approach that integrates functional genomics data and GWAS data to identify transcriptional mechanisms underlying tissue-specific pathology [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890]. By doing so, we expect to elucidate the connections between gene regulation and complex traits, ultimately contributing to the development of more effective treatments for diseases.

In this study, our method first integrates functional genomics data with GWAS data to identify transcriptional mechanisms underlying tissue-specific pathology. This approach allows us to fill the existing knowledge gap on gene regulation across different cell types and how it affects complex traits. Through the integration of these two types of data, we hope to enhance our understanding of the connections between gene regulation and disease processes. Ultimately, this research has the potential to inform the development of novel therapeutic targets and improve treatment strategies for diseases affected by complex traits.

---
 Gene expression patterns have been implicated in the etiology of various diseases, and understanding how genes regulate these patterns is essential for developing targeted treatments. However, existing knowledge on gene co-expression networks, genetic associations, and functional genomics has not yet provided a comprehensive framework to address this gap. In this study, we aim to bridge this gap by utilizing gene expression data and integrating it with genetic association studies to uncover the underlying mechanisms of disease development and drug action. By doing so, we hope to identify novel therapeutic targets and promote drug repurposing efforts.

Here, we have employed a novel approach that combines functional genomics data and GWAS data to shed light on the transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, contribute to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology. Our analysis revealed significant associations between gene co-expression patterns and complex traits, highlighting the potential of this method in uncovering disease etiologies and drug action mechanisms. Moreover, our findings have broader significance, as they pave the way for improved treatments and personalized medicine strategies.

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data can improve the identification of transcriptional mechanisms involved in disease development and drug action. This approach not only fills a gap in existing knowledge but also offers a promising avenue for future research, with the potential to advance our understanding of complex traits, disease etiologies, and drug mechanisms.

In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. ---
 Genes collaborate in context-specific networks to execute various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can shift their functional roles and, ultimately, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To comprehend how genes impact complex traits, it is crucial to elucidate gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which should contribute to the development of more effective treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous research has identified various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including genetic influences on gene expression across diverse tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has advanced the understanding of these transcriptional mechanisms, which, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/0810772105].

---
 Despite the fact that genes collaborate in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and impact disease-relevant biological processes, determining how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different cell types. Previous studies have described various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues. Integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that are dysregulated in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies. However, there is still a gap in our understanding of how gene co-expression patterns highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which is crucial for the development of novel therapeutic targets and drug repurposing strategies. This manuscript aims to fill this gap by employing a novel method that integrates genetic studies with functional genomics data to uncover the underlying connections between gene expression patterns, disease mechanisms, and potential drug targets. By doing so, we will provide insights into the broader context of understanding gene regulation in complex traits and contribute to the development of more effective treatments for various diseases.

Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

---
 Despite advances in understanding the role of genes in context-specific networks and their impact on disease-relevant biological processes, determining how genes influence complex traits requires a mechanistic understanding of expression regulation across different cell types. This understanding should lead to improved treatments for diseases. Although previous studies have described various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues, integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has not yet effectively captured the full extent of these transcriptional mechanisms. Here, we present a novel approach that fills this gap by systematically analyzing gene co-expression patterns in conjunction with genetic studies and functional genomics data to identify key regulators of gene expression and their role in disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This study not only contributes to the growing body of knowledge on gene regulation but also provides valuable insights into potential therapeutic targets and opportunities for drug repurposing, ultimately advancing our understanding of the broader context in which genes operate.

It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

outputs.text:
Python code returned false
len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1
---
 Genes operate in context-specific networks to carry out various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations within these genes can modify their functional roles, affecting disease-relevant biological processes at a higher level [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding how genes influence complex traits requires elucidating expression regulation across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to more effective treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including the genetic impact on gene expression across distinct tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms, which are often dysregulated and result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3].

In this revised version, the paragraph is rephrased to provide a clearer and more concise understanding of the importance of integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data in identifying transcriptional mechanisms that contribute to disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

---
 In the field of functional genomics, it is well established that genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. However, there is a gap in our understanding of how variations in these genes can change their functional role and affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To address this knowledge gap, the current study aims to determine how genes influence complex traits by mechanistically understanding gene expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which is crucial for improving treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Building upon previous studies that have described different regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across various tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], this research aims to integrate functional genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] to enhance our understanding of the transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314]. In doing so, this study aims to fill the existing gap in knowledge and contribute to the broader field of functional genomics by providing insights into gene expression regulation, its connection to disease etiology, and potential therapeutic targets.

In conclusion, our research seeks to address the current limitations in understanding gene function and expression patterns by integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data. This integration has the potential to significantly improve our understanding of transcriptional mechanisms that are crucial for elucidating disease etiology and identifying novel therapeutic targets. Our findings will not only fill an existing knowledge gap but also contribute to the broader field by offering a more comprehensive view of gene function, expression regulation, and their role in complex traits and diseases.

Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

vars: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

outputs.text: Genes collaborate in context-specific networks to execute various functions, as demonstrated by [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can alter their functional role and, consequently, impact disease-related biological processes, such as those studied in [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To elucidate how genes influence complex traits, it is crucial to understand the regulation of gene expression across diverse cell types, which should lead to enhanced therapeutic approaches [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous research has focused on identifying regulatory DNA elements, including genetic influences on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Combining functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when disrupted, often result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890].

---
 Genetic studies have shown that genes collaborate in context-specific networks to perform various functions, and their variations can change their functional roles and impact disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. However, understanding how these genes influence complex traits requires investigating expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Existing research has described various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-2020-2559-3]. However, there is a gap in the literature on how to integrate functional genomics data and GWAS data to identify transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890]. This study aims to address this gap by proposing a novel method that integrates functional genomics data and GWAS data, allowing for the identification of transcriptional mechanisms associated with disease etiology and drug mechanisms.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

---
 Genes collaborate within context-specific networks to perform various functions, as demonstrated by [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can impact their functional roles and ultimately affect disease-related biological processes, such as [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To elucidate the influence of genes on complex traits, it is crucial to understand gene expression regulation across different cell types, which may lead to more effective treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic impacts on gene expression across multiple tissues, e.g., [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. The integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data, such as [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890], has aided in the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, can result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1038/0810772105].

outputs.text: The existing literature has identified the significance of genes working together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions, and how variations in these genes can affect disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. However, there is a gap in the understanding of how genes influence complex traits through expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], a knowledge gap that needs to be addressed for improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. To fill this gap, our research integrates functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890], a method that has shown potential in improving the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. By addressing this gap and providing a comprehensive understanding of gene regulation, our research aims to contribute significantly to the field of genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, and drug repurposing by highlighting disease etiology and elucidating drug mechanisms.

You are a scientist with copy-editing skills who will help in improving the text of a manuscript with title 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' and keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Revise the following paragraph from the introduction of this manuscript so that it has a clear sentence structure, fits in a single paragraph, and keeps most references to papers (e.g. [@doi:...]). At a high level, the revision should highlight a gap in existing knowledge or methods, convey why it matters, and suggest how the manuscript aims to fill it. It may cover relevant literature to explain current knowledge, but only so far as is relevant to the motivation of the manuscript. It may be somewhat specific about results, relative to a typical high-level abstract section for example. More specifically, the revision should follow a context-content-conclusion (C-C-C) scheme, as follows: 1) The context portion communicates to the reader what gap the paper will fill. The first sentence orients the reader by introducing the broader field in which the manuscript's research is situated. Then, the context is narrowed until it lands on the open question that the research answers. A successful context section distinguishes the research’s contributions from the current state-of-the-art, communicating what is missing in the current literature (i.e., the specific gap) and why that matters (i.e. the connection between the specific gap and the broader context). 2) The content portion (e.g. "here we") first describes the novel method or approach that was used to fill the gap, then presents an executive summary of results. 3) The conclusion portion interprets the results to answer the question that was posed at the end of the context portion. There may be a second part to the conclusion portion that highlights how this conclusion moves the broader field forward (e.g. "broader significance").

Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

assert.value:
input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())
response = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 1.5 * input_words)
print(response)
